Posts.Content: Hi ladies I am the opposite way round to you and have had surgery with Chemo to follow.  Had mx on 14th July with imm implant reconstruction.  I can honestly say it wasn't as bad as I imagined.  I stayed in hospital for 2 nights and had 2 drains put in.  The first drain came out the day after I left hospital and the 2nd one 2 weeks after.  For me personally, the drain was the biggest pain!  By the end of the 2 weeks I kept walking off and forgetting to take it with me!  The pain wasn't too bad and I would describe it more as discomfort.  I was given Codeine to take home, and had the odd Ora-Morph whilst in hospital. Unfortunately I had to go back in for surgery last Tues to tidy the wound up as it wasn't healing as quick as they expected.  When I was in theatre it was discovered the implant wasn't right so they had to remove it.  Again I stayed in 2 nights and this time the second drain came out within 2 days.  I came out of hospital Thurs last week and I was back at work yesterday!  Yes it's sore and I feel a bit trussed up with wearing the sports bra etc but generally I am doing really well, so please try not to worry, easier said than done! Any questions, please do ask xx

Posts.Content: Hi I too had the predicament of node clearance. I was more worried about this op than the mx due to side effects etc. One node was affected with disease just touching 2mm. If it had been under 2mm I wouldn't have been offered the clearance. Plus all other nodes looked clear on ultrasound.  I spoke to one of the surgeons and he advised it may do more harm than good. I think Helsbels posted about affecting survival? My Consultant said the same, in his opinion it would not affect long time survival.  However the ONC said due to my age (39) he would advise it, another surgeon said the same.  So I went for it. All nodes removed were clear.  I only had the op in Aug but so far all ok. My arm is still numb on the underside / armpit, and it feels tingly most of the time.  Would I do the same again? Probably not. I would have gone with the Consultants advice. Easy for me to say though now I've done it! Xx

Posts.Title: From cancer to cross-country. A positive post.

Posts.Content: Hi Sarah  Sorry you've had to join us here but you can find some really good advice on here and some lovely people to share worries with.  I was diagnosed at the end of June with grade 2 BC. I have a 6 year old daughter and I told her more or less straight away. One thing I haven't said is the word Cancer. Mainly because she knows my mum passed away from it and also because at 6 she doesn't need to know or understand the ins and outs. I basically told her mummy wasn't well and had to go in hospital for an operation (mastectomy) and my boob would look different from before. She has seen it and wasn't bothered by it at all. She knows I'm having an implant and her opinion is "it'll be fine when it grows back"! I will be having chemo too and she did get upset when I said I may lose my hair. That passed in about 30 seconds! Although she has asked if I can get a different coloured wig everyday.  I try and answer any questions she has but to be honest she hasn't really asked much. Life is very much as normal for her. The only change was when I was in hospital. I had 3 ops in a month as as these occurred during the school hols she had to go to childcare and stayed with friends a couple of times. The change in routine did bother her a bit as she is very much a fan of routine! Once I was up and about though things settled down. Please try not to worry as I'm sure you're more worried about their reactions and they may surprise you. Kids are very resilient.  As for the surgery, it wasn't nearly as bad as I had feared. I stayed in hospital for 2 nights and once home just rested really for the first week on and off. For me the most annoying part were the drains. You come home with one or two drains which basically stay in until they are draining under a certain amount or they come out after a certain number of days. My daughter was fascinated by these and had to check every morning how much has come out! They don't hurt but after a while you forget they are there and end up walking away without them. I had mine for 13 days and it was a relief once they were out. I was lucky in terms of recovery and went back to work after 2 weeks. I could have gone back earlier if I had the drains removed.  Please be aware about potential post surgery blues too! After my 3 op and 4 days post surgery I burst into tears for no apparent reason and cried for about half an hour on my own like a snivelling wreck. Then fell asleep for 3 hours and woke up absolutely fine! The lovely people on here explained it was absolutely normal. You may not get it as after my mastectomy I was totally fine. Just don't worry that you've turned into a raving mad woman as it's very common. I'm sorry if I've gone on too much. I feel I've written the next War and Peace! But I just wanted you to know that you are not alone and this journey is doable. Yes you'll have days where you feel like screaming why me. But the further down the road you get and the more you know what's happening the better it is.  Hope that helps and wasn't too confusing.  Sending big hugs and please ask if you want to know anything else xx
